column13: Sonic focuses on providing broad access to our comprehensive range of high-quality medical services in all areas of operation: metropolitan, regional and rural. Our ongoing investment in modern facilities, automation and information technology, and the continuous expansion of our operational footprint produces efficiencies that benefit communities through improved access, faster turnaround times and lower costs for patients, insurers and the governments who often pay for our services.

Sonic Healthcare Limited delivers primary care services across a network of 215 clinics. Primary care services typically encompass a range of essential healthcare services provided by healthcare professionals, such as general practitioners, nurses, and allied health professionals, to address the primary healthcare needs of individuals and communities.

In recent years, Sonic has made significant investments in the digital technology and infrastructure required to ensure that our pathologists can provide clinicians and their patients with the highest quality specialized professional services while improving efficiency and capacity in our laboratories to enhance patient care. Digital pathology and artificial intelligence (AI) will radically transform anatomical pathology practice in the coming years.

The Sonic Healthcare Foundation facilitated the donation of a CT scanner to HEAL Africa in FY2023, helping to completely transform imaging diagnoses for the hospital's medical teams and their patients. The CT scanner, donated by Sonic Healthcare Australia's Canberra Imaging Group, undertook an arduous and complex journey to be safely delivered and installed at the HEAL Africa Hospital in Goma, Democratic Republic of Congo, Africa.

column7: In FY2022, Sonic Healthcare formalised its longstanding giving program. Sonic Healthcare contributed 40 million dollars to establish The Sonic Healthcare Foundation, an independent body established to fund charitable programs that improve the health and well-being of those in need.

column6: Proportion of spending on local suppliers
Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
column13: Our internal business assurance program (BAP) team and external auditors are responsible for monitoring Sonic's operations for risk of corruption. Any material breaches of the company's Anti-bribery and Corruption Policy, Code of Conduct or any material incidents reported under the company's Global Whistleblower Policy uncovered by the BAP team must be reported to the Audit Committee, which answers the Board.

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: Additional training on anti-corruption for senior management refers to providing further education and instruction on anti-corruption measures and practices to senior executives and leaders within an organization. This type of training is designed to enhance senior management's awareness, understanding, and skills in preventing, detecting, and addressing corruption-related risks within the organization.

column7: In FY 2023, There were no confirmed incidents of corruption during the reporting period.

column7: In FY 2023, There were no incidents concerning anti-competitive behaviour during the reporting period.

column13: On adopting the tax consolidation legislation, the entities in the tax-consolidated Group entered into a tax-sharing agreement. In the opinion of the Directors, the tax sharing agreement is a valid agreement under the tax consolidation legislation. It limits the joint and several liabilities of the wholly-owned entities in the case of a default by Sonic Healthcare Limited.

column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column7: Sonic Healthcare chose Group profit before tax because, in our view, it is the benchmark against which the performance of the Group is most commonly measured. Our team led the group audit from PwC Australia.

column6: Stakeholder engagement and management of concerns related to tax
column7: Sonic Healthcare seeks to maintain professional relationships with governments and tax authorities in our countries of operation, and we support constructive debate on taxation policy, including providing input where appropriate. Sonic sustain engagement with tax authorities and actively considers the implications of tax planning for Sonic Healthcare's wider reputation.

column13: Similar plastic packaging recycling projects are being introduced at other laboratories within Sonic, including many Australian laboratories. We also continue to work closely with suppliers to decrease the amount of plastic packaging used in the first instance.

Interactions with water as a shared resource
column13: Water purification systems are installed in all our large laboratories to provide purified water required by our analyzers. Water discharged from our facilities is tested and meets water quality regulations in all jurisdictions.

column6: Operational sites owned, leased, managed in, or adjacent to, protected areas and areas of high biodiversity value outside protected areas
Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: Sonic's operations generate significant amounts of waste, which can contribute to climate change and air pollution, directly affecting many ecosystems and species. Implementation and management of the board-approved environmental policies, which also address waste and the circular economy, are the responsibilities of the group CEO and the sustainability director, in conjunction with the Sonic Sustainability Steering Committee.

column7: Sonic's scope 1 emissions in 2023 were 32,503 tCO2e.
Sonic's scope 2 emissions in 2023 were 76,633 tCO2e.
Sonic's scope 3 emissions in 2023 were 483,257 tCO2e.
Sonic's greenhouse gas emissions intensity in 2023 was 3.29 tCO2e.

column13: While we await further development and infrastructure to support zero-emission vehicles, we continue to utilize hybrid technology to decrease fuel consumption. Sonic's fleet vehicles are typically renewed every three to five years, making hybrid cars an attractive interim scope 1 emissions-reduction initiative. At the same time, we await further development and infrastructure to support zero-emission vehicles.

Battery range extension refers to the enhancement or increase in the distance a battery-powered device or electric vehicle can travel on a single charge. This extension is achieved through various technological improvements, innovations, or optimisations to maximise the battery's energy efficiency and increase the device's overall range.
